Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Using Lessons from the Disaster in Japan to Develop Communications for Emergency Situations

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF: RAPID: Collaborative Research: Using Lessons from the Disaster in Japan to Develop Communications for Emergency Situations


During disasters, the telecommunication infrastructure are usually heavily damaged or overloaded, which leads to serious disruptions in the warning and rescue operations. Similarly, part of the Japanese cellular Early Earthquake Warning (EEW) system were damaged during the March 11th earthquake and tsunami. This collaborative project proposes to study the disruption of emergency communications during the last disaster in Japan and investigate corresponding solutions. In particular, the project has the following three integrated objectives: 1) To study the cellular EEW system of Japan and its use in the March 11th earthquake in Japan; 2) To study the communication problems that were encountered leading to disruptions in warning and rescue operations; and 3) To explore tower-less phone-to-phone direct communication mode that can make the cellular phone communications much more resilient during disasters.

This project supports collection of data about communication disruptions in Japan; treatment of such data to better understand the impact of telecommunication failures; and finally, solutions how to enhance the cellular system with ad hoc communications. The project is a close collaboration among PIs inthe US, their collaborators in Japanese universities and cellular service providers in Japan.

The outcome of this project will lead to a deeper understanding of tradeoffs among robustness, simplicity, scalability, self-organization and adaptivity in designing a cellular emergency broadcast system for USA and beyond. The results of this project will have a direct and practical impact on developing an effective emergency warning system using the latest communication devices.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project we studied the cellular Early Earthquake Warning (EEW) system used in the March 11th earthquake in Japan. More precisely, we studied the communication problems that were encountered leading to so many deaths and missing people. Furthermore we used our findings to develop a better cellular EEW that avoids its problems. In particular, to avoid its problems, we would like to explore new cellular communication modes such as tower-less phone-to-phone direct communication that is possible with new WiFi.

 The outcome of this project led us to a deeper understanding of tradeoffs among robustness, simplicity, scalability, self-organization and adaptivity in designing a cellular emergency broadcast system for USA. We will use traffic data regarding cellular, Internet and fixed traffic, from the disaster in Japan.

 Furthermore we developed a theoretical and simulation model for an adaptive wireless broadcast protocol, which depend on traffic load; network resources, such as node mobility, available energy of nodes; and requirements, such as reliability, delay, battery usage and network life.

 Based on our findings, we designed and developed the Adaptive Broadcast Protocol (ABP) for disaster communication situations. ABP uses the ad-hoc mode communication of smartphones based on WiFi, therefore could be a very valuable supplement of warning systems such as EEW.

 We tuned the tested our Adaptive Broadcast Protocol with traffic similar to disaster situations. We demonstrated that by trading delay and energy for traffic load and coverage, our protocol will adapt and provide much better communication service even in the worst disaster conditions.

 

The results of this project would have a direct and practical impact on developing an effective emergency warning system using the latest communication devices. In addition, three graduate students worked and were trained on the project. Finally, the conducted interdisciplinary research was integrated into teaching and learning activities, including two existing courses in networking and a new graduate course in mobile computing. The results were disseminated in prestigious international journals and conferences and in four workshops organized by the PIs.
